speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: PROLOGUE

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: In Troy, there lies the scene. From isles of Greece

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The princes orgulous, their high blood chafed,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Have to the port of Athens sent their ships,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Fraught with the ministers and instruments

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Of cruel war: sixty and nine, that wore

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Their crownets regal, from the Athenian bay

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Put forth toward Phrygia; and their vow is made

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To ransack Troy, within whose strong immures

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The ravish'd Helen, Menelaus' queen,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: With wanton Paris sleeps; and that's the quarrel.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To Tenedos they come;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And the deep-drawing barks do there disgorge

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Their warlike fraughtage: now on Dardan plains

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The fresh and yet unbruised Greeks do pitch

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Their brave pavilions: Priam's six-gated city,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Dardan, and Tymbria, Helias, Chetas, Troien,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And Antenorides, with massy staples

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And corresponsive and fulfilling bolts,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sperr up the sons of Troy.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Now expectation, tickling skittish spirits,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: On one and other side, Trojan and Greek,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sets all on hazard: and hither am I come

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: A prologue arm'd, but not in confidence

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Of author's pen or actor's voice, but suited

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: In like conditions as our argument,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To tell you, fair beholders, that our play

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Leaps o'er the vaunt and firstlings of those broils,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Beginning in the middle, starting thence away

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To what may be digested in a play.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Like or find fault; do as your pleasures are:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Now good or bad, 'tis but the chance of war.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter TROILUS armed, and PANDARUS

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Call here my varlet; I'll unarm again:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Why should I war without the walls of Troy,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That find such cruel battle here within?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Each Trojan that is master of his heart,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Let him to field; Troilus, alas! hath none.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Will this gear ne'er be mended?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The Greeks are strong and skilful to their strength,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Fierce to their skill and to their fierceness valiant;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But I am weaker than a woman's tear,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Tamer than sleep, fonder than ignorance,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Less valiant than the virgin in the night

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And skilless as unpractised infancy.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Well, I have told you enough of this: for my part,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I'll not meddle nor make no further. He that will

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: have a cake out of the wheat must needs tarry the grinding.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Have I not tarried?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Ay, the grinding; but you must tarry

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: the bolting.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Have I not tarried?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Ay, the bolting, but you must tarry the leavening.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Still have I tarried.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Ay, to the leavening; but here's yet in the word

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: 'hereafter' the kneading, the making of the cake, the

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: heating of the oven and the baking; nay, you must

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: stay the cooling too, or you may chance to burn your lips.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Patience herself, what goddess e'er she be,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Doth lesser blench at sufferance than I do.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: At Priam's royal table do I sit;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And when fair Cressid comes into my thoughts,--

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: So, traitor! 'When she comes!' When is she thence?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Well, she looked yesternight fairer than ever I saw

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: her look, or any woman else.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I was about to tell thee:--when my heart,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As wedged with a sigh, would rive in twain,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Lest Hector or my father should perceive me,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I have, as when the sun doth light a storm,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Buried this sigh in wrinkle of a smile:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But sorrow, that is couch'd in seeming gladness,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Is like that mirth fate turns to sudden sadness.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: An her hair were not somewhat darker than Helen's--

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: well, go to--there were no more comparison between

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: the women: but, for my part, she is my kinswoman; I

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: would not, as they term it, praise her: but I would

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: somebody had heard her talk yesterday, as I did. I

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: will not dispraise your sister Cassandra's wit, but--

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: O Pandarus! I tell thee, Pandarus,--

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: When I do tell thee, there my hopes lie drown'd,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Reply not in how many fathoms deep

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: They lie indrench'd. I tell thee I am mad

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: In Cressid's love: thou answer'st 'she is fair;'

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Pour'st in the open ulcer of my heart

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Her eyes, her hair, her cheek, her gait, her voice,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Handlest in thy discourse, O, that her hand,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: In whose comparison all whites are ink,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Writing their own reproach, to whose soft seizure

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The cygnet's down is harsh and spirit of sense

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Hard as the palm of ploughman: this thou tell'st me,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As true thou tell'st me, when I say I love her;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But, saying thus, instead of oil and balm,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Thou lay'st in every gash that love hath given me

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The knife that made it.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I speak no more than truth.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Thou dost not speak so much.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Faith, I'll not meddle in't. Let her be as she is:

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: if she be fair, 'tis the better for her; an she be

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: not, she has the mends in her own hands.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Good Pandarus, how now, Pandarus!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I have had my labour for my travail; ill-thought on of

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: her and ill-thought on of you; gone between and

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: between, but small thanks for my labour.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: What, art thou angry, Pandarus? what, with me?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Because she's kin to me, therefore she's not so fair

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: as Helen: an she were not kin to me, she would be as

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: fair on Friday as Helen is on Sunday. But what care

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I? I care not an she were a black-a-moor; 'tis all one to me.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Say I she is not fair?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I do not care whether you do or no. She's a fool to

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: stay behind her father; let her to the Greeks; and so

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I'll tell her the next time I see her: for my part,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I'll meddle nor make no more i' the matter.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Pandarus,--

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Not I.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Sweet Pandarus,--

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Pray you, speak no more to me: I will leave all as I

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: found it, and there an end.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Exit PANDARUS. An alarum

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Peace, you ungracious clamours! peace, rude sounds!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Fools on both sides! Helen must needs be fair,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: When with your blood you daily paint her thus.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I cannot fight upon this argument;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: It is too starved a subject for my sword.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But Pandarus,--O gods, how do you plague me!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I cannot come to Cressid but by Pandar;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And he's as tetchy to be woo'd to woo.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As she is stubborn-chaste against all suit.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Tell me, Apollo, for thy Daphne's love,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: What Cressid is, what Pandar, and what we?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Her bed is India; there she lies, a pearl:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Between our Ilium and where she resides,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Let it be call'd the wild and wandering flood,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Ourself the merchant, and this sailing Pandar

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Our doubtful hope, our convoy and our bark.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Alarum. Enter AENEAS

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: How now, Prince Troilus! wherefore not afield?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Because not there: this woman's answer sorts,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: For womanish it is to be from thence.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: What news, AEneas, from the field to-day?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: That Paris is returned home and hurt.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: By whom, AEneas?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Troilus, by Menelaus.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Let Paris bleed; 'tis but a scar to scorn;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Paris is gored with Menelaus' horn.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Alarum

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Hark, what good sport is out of town to-day!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Better at home, if 'would I might' were 'may.'

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But to the sport abroad: are you bound thither?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: In all swift haste.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Come, go we then together.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: SCENE II. The Same. A street.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Enter CRESSIDA and ALEXANDER

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Who were those went by?

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: Queen Hecuba and Helen.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: And whither go they?

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: Up to the eastern tower,

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: Whose height commands as subject all the vale,

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: To see the battle. Hector, whose patience

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: Is, as a virtue, fix'd, to-day was moved:

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: He chid Andromache and struck his armourer,

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: And, like as there were husbandry in war,

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: Before the sun rose he was harness'd light,

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: And to the field goes he; where every flower

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: Did, as a prophet, weep what it foresaw

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: In Hector's wrath.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: What was his cause of anger?

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: The noise goes, this: there is among the Greeks

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: A lord of Trojan blood, nephew to Hector;

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: They call him Ajax.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Good; and what of him?

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: They say he is a very man per se,

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: And stands alone.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: So do all men, unless they are drunk, sick, or have no legs.

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: This man, lady, hath robbed many beasts of their

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: particular additions; he is as valiant as the lion,

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: churlish as the bear, slow as the elephant: a man

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: into whom nature hath so crowded humours that his

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: valour is crushed into folly, his folly sauced with

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: discretion: there is no man hath a virtue that he

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: hath not a glimpse of, nor any man an attaint but he

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: carries some stain of it: he is melancholy without

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: cause, and merry against the hair: he hath the

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: joints of every thing, but everything so out of joint

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: that he is a gouty Briareus, many hands and no use,

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: or purblind Argus, all eyes and no sight.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: But how should this man, that makes

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: me smile, make Hector angry?

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: They say he yesterday coped Hector in the battle and

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: struck him down, the disdain and shame whereof hath

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: ever since kept Hector fasting and waking.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Who comes here?

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: Madam, your uncle Pandarus.

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: Enter PANDARUS

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Hector's a gallant man.

speaker: ALEXANDER
text_entry: As may be in the world, lady.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: What's that? what's that?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Good morrow, uncle Pandarus.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Good morrow, cousin Cressid: what do you talk of?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Good morrow, Alexander. How do you, cousin? When

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: were you at Ilium?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: This morning, uncle.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: What were you talking of when I came? Was Hector

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: armed and gone ere ye came to Ilium? Helen was not

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: up, was she?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Hector was gone, but Helen was not up.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Even so: Hector was stirring early.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: That were we talking of, and of his anger.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Was he angry?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: So he says here.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: True, he was so: I know the cause too: he'll lay

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: about him to-day, I can tell them that: and there's

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Troilus will not come far behind him: let them take

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: heed of Troilus, I can tell them that too.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: What, is he angry too?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Who, Troilus? Troilus is the better man of the two.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: O Jupiter! there's no comparison.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: What, not between Troilus and Hector? Do you know a

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: man if you see him?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Ay, if I ever saw him before and knew him.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Well, I say Troilus is Troilus.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Then you say as I say; for, I am sure, he is not Hector.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: No, nor Hector is not Troilus in some degrees.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: 'Tis just to each of them; he is himself.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Himself! Alas, poor Troilus! I would he were.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: So he is.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Condition, I had gone barefoot to India.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: He is not Hector.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Himself! no, he's not himself: would a' were

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: himself! Well, the gods are above; time must friend

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: or end: well, Troilus, well: I would my heart were

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: in her body. No, Hector is not a better man than Troilus.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Excuse me.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: He is elder.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Pardon me, pardon me.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Th' other's not come to't; you shall tell me another

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: tale, when th' other's come to't. Hector shall not

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: have his wit this year.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: He shall not need it, if he have his own.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Nor his qualities.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: No matter.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Nor his beauty.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: 'Twould not become him; his own's better.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: You have no judgment, niece: Helen

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: herself swore th' other day, that Troilus, for

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: a brown favour--for so 'tis, I must confess,--

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: not brown neither,--

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: No, but brown.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: 'Faith, to say truth, brown and not brown.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: To say the truth, true and not true.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: She praised his complexion above Paris.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Why, Paris hath colour enough.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: So he has.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Then Troilus should have too much: if she praised

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: him above, his complexion is higher than his; he

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: having colour enough, and the other higher, is too

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: flaming a praise for a good complexion. I had as

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: lief Helen's golden tongue had commended Troilus for

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: a copper nose.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I swear to you. I think Helen loves him better than Paris.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Then she's a merry Greek indeed.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Nay, I am sure she does. She came to him th' other

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: day into the compassed window,--and, you know, he

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: has not past three or four hairs on his chin,--

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Indeed, a tapster's arithmetic may soon bring his

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: particulars therein to a total.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Why, he is very young: and yet will he, within

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: three pound, lift as much as his brother Hector.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Is he so young a man and so old a lifter?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: But to prove to you that Helen loves him: she came

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: and puts me her white hand to his cloven chin--

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Juno have mercy! how came it cloven?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Why, you know 'tis dimpled: I think his smiling

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: becomes him better than any man in all Phrygia.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: O, he smiles valiantly.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Does he not?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: O yes, an 'twere a cloud in autumn.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Why, go to, then: but to prove to you that Helen

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: loves Troilus,--

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Troilus will stand to the proof, if you'll

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: prove it so.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Troilus! why, he esteems her no more than I esteem

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: an addle egg.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: If you love an addle egg as well as you love an idle

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: head, you would eat chickens i' the shell.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I cannot choose but laugh, to think how she tickled

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: his chin: indeed, she has a marvellous white hand, I

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: must needs confess,--

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Without the rack.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: And she takes upon her to spy a white hair on his chin.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Alas, poor chin! many a wart is richer.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: But there was such laughing! Queen Hecuba laughed

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: that her eyes ran o'er.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: With mill-stones.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: And Cassandra laughed.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: But there was more temperate fire under the pot of

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: her eyes: did her eyes run o'er too?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: And Hector laughed.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: At what was all this laughing?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Marry, at the white hair that Helen spied on Troilus' chin.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: An't had been a green hair, I should have laughed

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: too.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: They laughed not so much at the hair as at his pretty answer.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: What was his answer?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Quoth she, 'Here's but two and fifty hairs on your

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: chin, and one of them is white.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: This is her question.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: That's true; make no question of that. 'Two and

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: fifty hairs' quoth he, 'and one white: that white

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: hair is my father, and all the rest are his sons.'

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: 'Jupiter!' quoth she, 'which of these hairs is Paris,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: my husband? 'The forked one,' quoth he, 'pluck't

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: out, and give it him.' But there was such laughing!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: and Helen so blushed, an Paris so chafed, and all the

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: rest so laughed, that it passed.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: So let it now; for it has been while going by.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Well, cousin. I told you a thing yesterday; think on't.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: So I do.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I'll be sworn 'tis true; he will weep you, an 'twere

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: a man born in April.

speaker: CRESSIDA

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Yes, lion-sick, sick of proud heart: you may call it

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: melancholy, if you will favour the man; but, by my

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: head, 'tis pride: but why, why? let him show us the

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: cause. A word, my lord.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Takes AGAMEMNON aside

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: What moves Ajax thus to bay at him?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Achilles hath inveigled his fool from him.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Who, Thersites?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Then will Ajax lack matter, if he have lost his argument.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: No, you see, he is his argument that has his

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: argument, Achilles.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: All the better; their fraction is more our wish than

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: their faction: but it was a strong composure a fool

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: could disunite.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: untie. Here comes Patroclus.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Re-enter PATROCLUS

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: No Achilles with him.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The elephant hath joints, but none for courtesy:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: his legs are legs for necessity, not for flexure.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Achilles bids me say, he is much sorry,

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: If any thing more than your sport and pleasure

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Did move your greatness and this noble state

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: To call upon him; he hopes it is no other

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: But for your health and your digestion sake,

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: And after-dinner's breath.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Hear you, Patroclus:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: We are too well acquainted with these answers:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: But his evasion, wing'd thus swift with scorn,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Cannot outfly our apprehensions.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Much attribute he hath, and much the reason

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Why we ascribe it to him; yet all his virtues,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Not virtuously on his own part beheld,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Do in our eyes begin to lose their gloss,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Yea, like fair fruit in an unwholesome dish,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Are like to rot untasted. Go and tell him,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: We come to speak with him; and you shall not sin,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: If you do say we think him over-proud

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: And under-honest, in self-assumption greater

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Than in the note of judgment; and worthier

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: than himself

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Here tend the savage strangeness he puts on,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Disguise the holy strength of their command,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: And underwrite in an observing kind

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: His humorous predominance; yea, watch

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: His pettish lunes, his ebbs, his flows, as if

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: The passage and whole carriage of this action

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Rode on his tide. Go tell him this, and add,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: That if he overhold his price so much,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: We'll none of him; but let him, like an engine

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Not portable, lie under this report:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: 'Bring action hither, this cannot go to war:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: A stirring dwarf we do allowance give

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Before a sleeping giant.' Tell him so.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: I shall; and bring his answer presently.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: In second voice we'll not be satisfied;

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: We come to speak with him. Ulysses, enter you.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Exit ULYSSES

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: What is he more than another?

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: No more than what he thinks he is.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Is he so much? Do you not think he thinks himself a

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: better man than I am?

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: No question.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Will you subscribe his thought, and say he is?

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: No, noble Ajax; you are as strong, as valiant, as

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: wise, no less noble, much more gentle, and altogether

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: more tractable.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Why should a man be proud? How doth pride grow? I

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: know not what pride is.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Your mind is the clearer, Ajax, and your virtues the

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: fairer. He that is proud eats up himself: pride is

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: his own glass, his own trumpet, his own chronicle;

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: and whatever praises itself but in the deed, devours

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: the deed in the praise.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: I do hate a proud man, as I hate the engendering of toads.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Yet he loves himself: is't not strange?

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Aside

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Re-enter ULYSSES

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Achilles will not to the field to-morrow.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: What's his excuse?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He doth rely on none,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: But carries on the stream of his dispose

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Without observance or respect of any,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: In will peculiar and in self-admission.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Why will he not upon our fair request

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Untent his person and share the air with us?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Things small as nothing, for request's sake only,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He makes important: possess'd he is with greatness,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And speaks not to himself but with a pride

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That quarrels at self-breath: imagined worth

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Holds in his blood such swoln and hot discourse

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That 'twixt his mental and his active parts

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Kingdom'd Achilles in commotion rages

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And batters down himself: what should I say?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He is so plaguy proud that the death-tokens of it

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Cry 'No recovery.'

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Let Ajax go to him.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Dear lord, go you and greet him in his tent:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: 'Tis said he holds you well, and will be led

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: At your request a little from himself.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: O Agamemnon, let it not be so!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: We'll consecrate the steps that Ajax makes

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: When they go from Achilles: shall the proud lord

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That bastes his arrogance with his own seam

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And never suffers matter of the world

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Enter his thoughts, save such as do revolve

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And ruminate himself, shall he be worshipp'd

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Of that we hold an idol more than he?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: No, this thrice worthy and right valiant lord

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Must not so stale his palm, nobly acquired;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Nor, by my will, assubjugate his merit,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: As amply titled as Achilles is,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: By going to Achilles:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That were to enlard his fat already pride

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And add more coals to Cancer when he burns

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: With entertaining great Hyperion.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: This lord go to him! Jupiter forbid,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And say in thunder 'Achilles go to him.'

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: [Aside to DIOMEDES]  O, this is well; he rubs the

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: vein of him.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: [Aside to NESTOR]  And how his silence drinks up

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: this applause!

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: If I go to him, with my armed fist I'll pash him o'er the face.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: O, no, you shall not go.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: An a' be proud with me, I'll pheeze his pride:

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Let me go to him.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Not for the worth that hangs upon our quarrel.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: A paltry, insolent fellow!

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: How he describes himself!

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Can he not be sociable?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The raven chides blackness.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: I'll let his humours blood.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: He will be the physician that should be the patient.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: An all men were o' my mind,--

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Wit would be out of fashion.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: A' should not bear it so, a' should eat swords first:

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: shall pride carry it?

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: An 'twould, you'ld carry half.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: A' would have ten shares.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: I will knead him; I'll make him supple.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: He's not yet through warm: force him with praises:

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: pour in, pour in; his ambition is dry.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: [To AGAMEMNON]  My lord, you feed too much on this dislike.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Our noble general, do not do so.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: You must prepare to fight without Achilles.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Why, 'tis this naming of him does him harm.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Here is a man--but 'tis before his face;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: I will be silent.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Wherefore should you so?

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: He is not emulous, as Achilles is.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Know the whole world, he is as valiant.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: A whoreson dog, that shall pelter thus with us!

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Would he were a Trojan!

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: What a vice were it in Ajax now,--

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: If he were proud,--

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Or covetous of praise,--

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Ay, or surly borne,--

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Or strange, or self-affected!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Thank the heavens, lord, thou art of sweet composure;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Praise him that got thee, she that gave thee suck:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Famed be thy tutor, and thy parts of nature

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Thrice famed, beyond all erudition:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: But he that disciplined thy arms to fight,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Let Mars divide eternity in twain,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And give him half: and, for thy vigour,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Bull-bearing Milo his addition yield

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To sinewy Ajax. I will not praise thy wisdom,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Which, like a bourn, a pale, a shore, confines

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Thy spacious and dilated parts: here's Nestor;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Instructed by the antiquary times,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He must, he is, he cannot but be wise:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Put pardon, father Nestor, were your days

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: As green as Ajax' and your brain so temper'd,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: You should not have the eminence of him,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: But be as Ajax.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Shall I call you father?

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Ay, my good son.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Be ruled by him, Lord Ajax.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: There is no tarrying here; the hart Achilles

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Keeps thicket. Please it our great general

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To call together all his state of war;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Fresh kings are come to Troy: to-morrow

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: We must with all our main of power stand fast:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And here's a lord,--come knights from east to west,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And cull their flower, Ajax shall cope the best.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Go we to council. Let Achilles sleep:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Light boats sail swift, though greater hulks draw deep.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Enter a Servant and PANDARUS

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Friend, you! pray you, a word: do not you follow

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: the young Lord Paris?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Ay, sir, when he goes before me.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: You depend upon him, I mean?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Sir, I do depend upon the lord.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: You depend upon a noble gentleman; I must needs

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: praise him.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: The lord be praised!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: You know me, do you not?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Faith, sir, superficially.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Friend, know me better; I am the Lord Pandarus.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: I hope I shall know your honour better.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I do desire it.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: You are in the state of grace.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Grace! not so, friend: honour and lordship are my titles.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Music within

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: What music is this?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: I do but partly know, sir: it is music in parts.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Know you the musicians?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Wholly, sir.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Who play they to?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: To the hearers, sir.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: At whose pleasure, friend

speaker: Servant
text_entry: At mine, sir, and theirs that love music.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Command, I mean, friend.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Who shall I command, sir?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Friend, we understand not one another: I am too

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: courtly and thou art too cunning. At whose request

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: do these men play?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: That's to 't indeed, sir: marry, sir, at the request

speaker: Servant
text_entry: of Paris my lord, who's there in person; with him,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: the mortal Venus, the heart-blood of beauty, love's

speaker: Servant
text_entry: invisible soul,--

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Who, my cousin Cressida?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: No, sir, Helen: could you not find out that by her

speaker: Servant
text_entry: attributes?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: It should seem, fellow, that thou hast not seen the

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Lady Cressida. I come to speak with Paris from the

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Prince Troilus: I will make a complimental assault

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: upon him, for my business seethes.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Sodden business! there's a stewed phrase indeed!

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Enter PARIS and HELEN, attended

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Fair be to you, my lord, and to all this fair

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: company! fair desires, in all fair measure,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: fairly guide them! especially to you, fair queen!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: fair thoughts be your fair pillow!

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: Dear lord, you are full of fair words.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: You speak your fair pleasure, sweet queen. Fair

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: prince, here is good broken music.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: You have broke it, cousin: and, by my life, you

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: shall make it whole again; you shall piece it out

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: with a piece of your performance. Nell, he is full

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: of harmony.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Truly, lady, no.

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: O, sir,--

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Rude, in sooth; in good sooth, very rude.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Well said, my lord! well, you say so in fits.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I have business to my lord, dear queen. My lord,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: will you vouchsafe me a word?

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: Nay, this shall not hedge us out: we'll hear you

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: sing, certainly.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Well, sweet queen. you are pleasant with me. But,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: marry, thus, my lord: my dear lord and most esteemed

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: friend, your brother Troilus,--

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: My Lord Pandarus; honey-sweet lord,--

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Go to, sweet queen, to go:--commends himself most

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: affectionately to you,--

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: You shall not bob us out of our melody: if you do,

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: our melancholy upon your head!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Sweet queen, sweet queen! that's a sweet queen, i' faith.

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: And to make a sweet lady sad is a sour offence.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Nay, that shall not serve your turn; that shall not,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: in truth, la. Nay, I care not for such words; no,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: no. And, my lord, he desires you, that if the king

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: call for him at supper, you will make his excuse.

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: My Lord Pandarus,--

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: What says my sweet queen, my very very sweet queen?

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: What exploit's in hand? where sups he to-night?

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: Nay, but, my lord,--

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: What says my sweet queen? My cousin will fall out

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: with you. You must not know where he sups.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: I'll lay my life, with my disposer Cressida.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: No, no, no such matter; you are wide: come, your

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: disposer is sick.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Well, I'll make excuse.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Ay, good my lord. Why should you say Cressida? no,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: your poor disposer's sick.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: I spy.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: You spy! what do you spy? Come, give me an

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: instrument. Now, sweet queen.

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: Why, this is kindly done.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: My niece is horribly in love with a thing you have,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: sweet queen.

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: She shall have it, my lord, if it be not my lord Paris.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: He! no, she'll none of him; they two are twain.

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: Falling in, after falling out, may make them three.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Come, come, I'll hear no more of this; I'll sing

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: you a song now.

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: Ay, ay, prithee now. By my troth, sweet lord, thou

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: hast a fine forehead.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Ay, you may, you may.

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: Let thy song be love: this love will undo us all.

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: O Cupid, Cupid, Cupid!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Love! ay, that it shall, i' faith.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Ay, good now, love, love, nothing but love.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: In good troth, it begins so.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Sings

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Love, love, nothing but love, still more!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: For, O, love's bow

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Shoots buck and doe:

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: The shaft confounds,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Not that it wounds,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: But tickles still the sore.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: These lovers cry Oh! oh! they die!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Yet that which seems the wound to kill,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Doth turn oh! oh! to ha! ha! he!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: So dying love lives still:

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Oh! oh! a while, but ha! ha! ha!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Oh! oh! groans out for ha! ha! ha!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Heigh-ho!

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: In love, i' faith, to the very tip of the nose.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: He eats nothing but doves, love, and that breeds hot

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: blood, and hot blood begets hot thoughts, and hot

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: thoughts beget hot deeds, and hot deeds is love.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Is this the generation of love? hot blood, hot

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: thoughts, and hot deeds? Why, they are vipers:

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: is love a generation of vipers? Sweet lord, who's

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: a-field to-day?

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Hector, Deiphobus, Helenus, Antenor, and all the

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: gallantry of Troy: I  would fain have armed to-day,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: but my Nell would not have it so. How chance my

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: brother Troilus went not?

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: He hangs the lip at something: you know all, Lord Pandarus.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Not I, honey-sweet queen. I long to hear how they

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: sped to-day. You'll remember your brother's excuse?

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: To a hair.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Farewell, sweet queen.

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: Commend me to your niece.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I will, sweet queen.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: A retreat sounded

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: They're come from field: let us to Priam's hall,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: To greet the warriors. Sweet Helen, I must woo you

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: To help unarm our Hector: his stubborn buckles,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: With these your white enchanting fingers touch'd,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Shall more obey than to the edge of steel

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Or force of Greekish sinews; you shall do more

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Than all the island kings,--disarm great Hector.

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: 'Twill make us proud to be his servant, Paris;

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: Yea, what he shall receive of us in duty

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: Gives us more palm in beauty than we have,

speaker: HELEN
text_entry: Yea, overshines ourself.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Sweet, above thought I love thee.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Enter PANDARUS and Troilus's Boy, meeting

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: How now! where's thy master? at my cousin

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Cressida's?

speaker: Boy
text_entry: No, sir; he stays for you to conduct him thither.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: O, here he comes.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Enter TROILUS

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: How now, how now!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Sirrah, walk off.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Exit Boy

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Have you seen my cousin?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: No, Pandarus: I stalk about her door,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Like a strange soul upon the Stygian banks

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Staying for waftage. O, be thou my Charon,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And give me swift transportance to those fields

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Where I may wallow in the lily-beds

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Proposed for the deserver! O gentle Pandarus,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: From Cupid's shoulder pluck his painted wings

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And fly with me to Cressid!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Walk here i' the orchard, I'll bring her straight.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I am giddy; expectation whirls me round.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The imaginary relish is so sweet

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That it enchants my sense: what will it be,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: When that the watery palate tastes indeed

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Love's thrice repured nectar? death, I fear me,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Swooning destruction, or some joy too fine,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Too subtle-potent, tuned too sharp in sweetness,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: For the capacity of my ruder powers:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I fear it much; and I do fear besides,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That I shall lose distinction in my joys;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As doth a battle, when they charge on heaps

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The enemy flying.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Re-enter PANDARUS

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: She's making her ready, she'll come straight: you

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: must be witty now. She does so blush, and fetches

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: her wind so short, as if she were frayed with a

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: sprite: I'll fetch her. It is the prettiest

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: villain: she fetches her breath as short as a

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: new-ta'en sparrow.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Even such a passion doth embrace my bosom:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: My heart beats thicker than a feverous pulse;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And all my powers do their bestowing lose,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Like vassalage at unawares encountering

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The eye of majesty.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Re-enter PANDARUS with CRESSIDA

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Come, come, what need you blush? shame's a baby.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Here she is now: swear the oaths now to her that

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: you have sworn to me. What, are you gone again?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: you must be watched ere you be made tame, must you?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Come your ways, come your ways; an you draw backward,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: we'll put you i' the fills. Why do you not speak to

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: her? Come, draw this curtain, and let's see your

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: picture. Alas the day, how loath you are to offend

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: daylight! an 'twere dark, you'ld close sooner.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: So, so; rub on, and kiss the mistress. How now!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: a kiss in fee-farm! build there, carpenter; the air

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: is sweet. Nay, you shall fight your hearts out ere

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I part you. The falcon as the tercel, for all the

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: ducks i' the river: go to, go to.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: You have bereft me of all words, lady.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Words pay no debts, give her deeds: but she'll

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: bereave you o' the deeds too, if she call your

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: activity in question. What, billing again? Here's

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: 'In witness whereof the parties interchangeably'--

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Come in, come in: I'll go get a fire.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Will you walk in, my lord?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: O Cressida, how often have I wished me thus!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Wished, my lord! The gods grant,--O my lord!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: What should they grant? what makes this pretty

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: abruption? What too curious dreg espies my sweet

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: lady in the fountain of our love?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: More dregs than water, if my fears have eyes.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Fears make devils of cherubims; they never see truly.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Blind fear, that seeing reason leads, finds safer

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: footing than blind reason stumbling without fear: to

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: fear the worst oft cures the worse.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: O, let my lady apprehend no fear: in all Cupid's

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: pageant there is presented no monster.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Nor nothing monstrous neither?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Nothing, but our undertakings; when we vow to weep

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: seas, live in fire, eat rocks, tame tigers; thinking

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: it harder for our mistress to devise imposition

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: enough than for us to undergo any difficulty imposed.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: This is the monstruosity in love, lady, that the will

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: is infinite and the execution confined, that the

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: desire is boundless and the act a slave to limit.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: They say all lovers swear more performance than they

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: are able and yet reserve an ability that they never

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: perform, vowing more than the perfection of ten and

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: discharging less than the tenth part of one. They

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: that have the voice of lions and the act of hares,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: are they not monsters?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Are there such? such are not we: praise us as we

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: are tasted, allow us as we prove; our head shall go

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: bare till merit crown it: no perfection in reversion

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: shall have a praise in present: we will not name

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: desert before his birth, and, being born, his addition

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: shall be humble. Few words to fair faith: Troilus

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: shall be such to Cressid as what envy can say worst

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: shall be a mock for his truth, and what truth can

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: speak truest not truer than Troilus.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Will you walk in, my lord?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Re-enter PANDARUS

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: What, blushing still? have you not done talking yet?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Well, uncle, what folly I commit, I dedicate to you.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I thank you for that: if my lord get a boy of you,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: you'll give him me. Be true to my lord: if he

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: flinch, chide me for it.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: You know now your hostages; your uncle's word and my

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: firm faith.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Nay, I'll give my word for her too: our kindred,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: though they be long ere they are wooed, they are

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: constant being won: they are burs, I can tell you;

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: they'll stick where they are thrown.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Boldness comes to me now, and brings me heart.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Prince Troilus, I have loved you night and day

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: For many weary months.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Why was my Cressid then so hard to win?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Hard to seem won: but I was won, my lord,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: With the first glance that ever--pardon me--

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: If I confess much, you will play the tyrant.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I love you now; but not, till now, so much

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: But I might master it: in faith, I lie;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: My thoughts were like unbridled children, grown

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Too headstrong for their mother. See, we fools!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Why have I blabb'd? who shall be true to us,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: When we are so unsecret to ourselves?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: But, though I loved you well, I woo'd you not;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: And yet, good faith, I wish'd myself a man,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Or that we women had men's privilege

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Of speaking first. Sweet, bid me hold my tongue,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: For in this rapture I shall surely speak

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: The thing I shall repent. See, see, your silence,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Cunning in dumbness, from my weakness draws

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: My very soul of counsel! stop my mouth.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And shall, albeit sweet music issues thence.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Pretty, i' faith.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: My lord, I do beseech you, pardon me;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: 'Twas not my purpose, thus to beg a kiss:

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I am ashamed. O heavens! what have I done?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: For this time will I take my leave, my lord.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Your leave, sweet Cressid!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Leave! an you take leave till to-morrow morning,--

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Pray you, content you.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: What offends you, lady?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Sir, mine own company.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: You cannot shun Yourself.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Let me go and try:

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I have a kind of self resides with you;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: But an unkind self, that itself will leave,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: To be another's fool. I would be gone:

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Where is my wit? I know not what I speak.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Well know they what they speak that speak so wisely.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Perchance, my lord, I show more craft than love;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: And fell so roundly to a large confession,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: To angle for your thoughts: but you are wise,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Or else you love not, for to be wise and love

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Exceeds man's might; that dwells with gods above.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: O that I thought it could be in a woman--

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As, if it can, I will presume in you--

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To feed for aye her ramp and flames of love;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To keep her constancy in plight and youth,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Outliving beauty's outward, with a mind

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That doth renew swifter than blood decays!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Or that persuasion could but thus convince me,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That my integrity and truth to you

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Might be affronted with the match and weight

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Of such a winnow'd purity in love;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: How were I then uplifted! but, alas!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I am as true as truth's simplicity

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And simpler than the infancy of truth.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: In that I'll war with you.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: O virtuous fight,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: When right with right wars who shall be most right!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: True swains in love shall in the world to come

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Approve their truths by Troilus: when their rhymes,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Full of protest, of oath and big compare,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Want similes, truth tired with iteration,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As true as steel, as plantage to the moon,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As sun to day, as turtle to her mate,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As iron to adamant, as earth to the centre,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Yet, after all comparisons of truth,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As truth's authentic author to be cited,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: 'As true as Troilus' shall crown up the verse,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And sanctify the numbers.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Prophet may you be!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: If I be false, or swerve a hair from truth,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: When time is old and hath forgot itself,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: When waterdrops have worn the stones of Troy,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: And blind oblivion swallow'd cities up,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: And mighty states characterless are grated

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: To dusty nothing, yet let memory,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: From false to false, among false maids in love,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Upbraid my falsehood! when they've said 'as false

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: As air, as water, wind, or sandy earth,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: As fox to lamb, as wolf to heifer's calf,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Pard to the hind, or stepdame to her son,'

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: 'Yea,' let them say, to stick the heart of falsehood,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: 'As false as Cressid.'

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Go to, a bargain made: seal it, seal it; I'll be the

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: witness. Here I hold your hand, here my cousin's.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: If ever you prove false one to another, since I have

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: taken such pains to bring you together, let all

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: pitiful goers-between be called to the world's end

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: after my name; call them all Pandars; let all

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: constant men be Troiluses, all false women Cressids,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: and all brokers-between Pandars! say, amen.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Amen.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Amen.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Amen. Whereupon I will show you a chamber with a

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: bed; which bed, because it shall not speak of your

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: pretty encounters, press it to death: away!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: And Cupid grant all tongue-tied maidens here

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Bed, chamber, Pandar to provide this gear!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, DIOMEDES, NESTOR, AJAX, MENELAUS, and CALCHAS

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Now, princes, for the service I have done you,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: The advantage of the time prompts me aloud

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: To call for recompense. Appear it to your mind

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: That, through the sight I bear in things to love,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: I have abandon'd Troy, left my possession,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Incurr'd a traitor's name; exposed myself,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: From certain and possess'd conveniences,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: To doubtful fortunes; sequestering from me all

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: That time, acquaintance, custom and condition

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Made tame and most familiar to my nature,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: And here, to do you service, am become

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: As new into the world, strange, unacquainted:

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: I do beseech you, as in way of taste,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: To give me now a little benefit,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Out of those many register'd in promise,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Which, you say, live to come in my behalf.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: What wouldst thou of us, Trojan? make demand.

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: You have a Trojan prisoner, call'd Antenor,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Yesterday took: Troy holds him very dear.

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Oft have you--often have you thanks therefore--

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Desired my Cressid in right great exchange,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Whom Troy hath still denied: but this Antenor,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: I know, is such a wrest in their affairs

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: That their negotiations all must slack,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Wanting his manage; and they will almost

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Give us a prince of blood, a son of Priam,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: In change of him: let him be sent, great princes,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: And he shall buy my daughter; and her presence

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Shall quite strike off all service I have done,

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: In most accepted pain.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Let Diomedes bear him,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: And bring us Cressid hither: Calchas shall have

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: What he requests of us. Good Diomed,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Furnish you fairly for this interchange:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Withal bring word if Hector will to-morrow

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Be answer'd in his challenge: Ajax is ready.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: This shall I undertake; and 'tis a burden

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Which I am proud to bear.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Exeunt DIOMEDES and CALCHAS

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS, before their tent

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Achilles stands i' the entrance of his tent:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Please it our general to pass strangely by him,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: As if he were forgot; and, princes all,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Lay negligent and loose regard upon him:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: I will come last. 'Tis like he'll question me

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Why such unplausive eyes are bent on him:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: If so, I have derision medicinable,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To use between your strangeness and his pride,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Which his own will shall have desire to drink:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: It may be good: pride hath no other glass

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To show itself but pride, for supple knees

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Feed arrogance and are the proud man's fees.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: We'll execute your purpose, and put on

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: A form of strangeness as we pass along:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: So do each lord, and either greet him not,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Or else disdainfully, which shall shake him more

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Than if not look'd on. I will lead the way.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: What, comes the general to speak with me?

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: You know my mind, I'll fight no more 'gainst Troy.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: What says Achilles? would he aught with us?

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Would you, my lord, aught with the general?

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: No.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Nothing, my lord.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: The better.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Exeunt AGAMEMNON and NESTOR

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Good day, good day.

speaker: MENELAUS
text_entry: How do you? how do you?

speaker: MENELAUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: What, does the cuckold scorn me?

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: How now, Patroclus!

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Good morrow, Ajax.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Ha?

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Good morrow.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Ay, and good next day too.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: What mean these fellows? Know they not Achilles?

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: They pass by strangely: they were used to bend

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: To send their smiles before them to Achilles;

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: To come as humbly as they used to creep

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: To holy altars.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: What, am I poor of late?

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: 'Tis certain, greatness, once fall'n out with fortune,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Must fall out with men too: what the declined is

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: He shall as soon read in the eyes of others

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: As feel in his own fall; for men, like butterflies,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Show not their mealy wings but to the summer,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: And not a man, for being simply man,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Hath any honour, but honour for those honours

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: That are without him, as place, riches, favour,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Prizes of accident as oft as merit:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Which when they fall, as being slippery standers,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: The love that lean'd on them as slippery too,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Do one pluck down another and together

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Die in the fall. But 'tis not so with me:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Fortune and I are friends: I do enjoy

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: At ample point all that I did possess,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Save these men's looks; who do, methinks, find out

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Something not worth in me such rich beholding

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: As they have often given. Here is Ulysses;

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: I'll interrupt his reading.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: How now Ulysses!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Now, great Thetis' son!

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: What are you reading?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: A strange fellow here

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Writes me: 'That man, how dearly ever parted,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: How much in having, or without or in,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Cannot make boast to have that which he hath,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Nor feels not what he owes, but by reflection;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: As when his virtues shining upon others

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Heat them and they retort that heat again

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To the first giver.'

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: This is not strange, Ulysses.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: The beauty that is borne here in the face

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: The bearer knows not, but commends itself

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: To others' eyes; nor doth the eye itself,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: That most pure spirit of sense, behold itself,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Not going from itself; but eye to eye opposed

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Salutes each other with each other's form;

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: For speculation turns not to itself,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Till it hath travell'd and is mirror'd there

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Where it may see itself. This is not strange at all.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: I do not strain at the position,--

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: It is familiar,--but at the author's drift;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Who, in his circumstance, expressly proves

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That no man is the lord of any thing,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Though in and of him there be much consisting,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Till he communicate his parts to others:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Nor doth he of himself know them for aught

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Till he behold them form'd in the applause

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Where they're extended; who, like an arch,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: reverberates

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The voice again, or, like a gate of steel

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Fronting the sun, receives and renders back

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: His figure and his heat.  I was much wrapt in this;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And apprehended here immediately

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The unknown Ajax.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Heavens, what a man is there! a very horse,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That has he knows not what. Nature, what things there are

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Most abject in regard and dear in use!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: What things again most dear in the esteem

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And poor in worth! Now shall we see to-morrow--

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: An act that very chance doth throw upon him--

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Ajax renown'd. O heavens, what some men do,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: While some men leave to do!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: How some men creep in skittish fortune's hall,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Whiles others play the idiots in her eyes!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: How one man eats into another's pride,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: While pride is fasting in his wantonness!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To see these Grecian lords!--why, even already

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: They clap the lubber Ajax on the shoulder,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: As if his foot were on brave Hector's breast

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And great Troy shrieking.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: I do believe it; for they pass'd by me

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: As misers do by beggars, neither gave to me

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Good word nor look: what, are my deeds forgot?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Time hath, my lord, a wallet at his back,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Wherein he puts alms for oblivion,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: A great-sized monster of ingratitudes:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Those scraps are good deeds past; which are devour'd

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: As fast as they are made, forgot as soon

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: As done: perseverance, dear my lord,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Keeps honour bright: to have done is to hang

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Quite out of fashion, like a rusty mail

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: In monumental mockery. Take the instant way;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: For honour travels in a strait so narrow,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Where one but goes abreast: keep then the path;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: For emulation hath a thousand sons

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That one by one pursue: if you give way,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Or hedge aside from the direct forthright,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Like to an enter'd tide, they all rush by

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And leave you hindmost;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Or like a gallant horse fall'n in first rank,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Lie there for pavement to the abject rear,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: O'er-run and trampled on: then what they do in present,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Though less than yours in past, must o'ertop yours;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: For time is like a fashionable host

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That slightly shakes his parting guest by the hand,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And with his arms outstretch'd, as he would fly,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Grasps in the comer: welcome ever smiles,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And farewell goes out sighing. O, let not

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: virtue seek

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Remuneration for the thing it was;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: For beauty, wit,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: High birth, vigour of bone, desert in service,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Love, friendship, charity, are subjects all

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To envious and calumniating time.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: One touch of nature makes the whole world kin,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That all with one consent praise new-born gawds,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Though they are made and moulded of things past,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And give to dust that is a little gilt

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: More laud than gilt o'er-dusted.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The present eye praises the present object.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Then marvel not, thou great and complete man,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That all the Greeks begin to worship Ajax;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Since things in motion sooner catch the eye

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Than what not stirs. The cry went once on thee,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And still it might, and yet it may again,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: If thou wouldst not entomb thyself alive

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And case thy reputation in thy tent;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Whose glorious deeds, but in these fields of late,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Made emulous missions 'mongst the gods themselves

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And drave great Mars to faction.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Of this my privacy

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: I have strong reasons.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: But 'gainst your privacy

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The reasons are more potent and heroical:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: 'Tis known, Achilles, that you are in love

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: With one of Priam's daughters.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Ha! known!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Is that a wonder?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The providence that's in a watchful state

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Knows almost every grain of Plutus' gold,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Finds bottom in the uncomprehensive deeps,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Keeps place with thought and almost, like the gods,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Does thoughts unveil in their dumb cradles.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: There is a mystery--with whom relation

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Durst never meddle--in the soul of state;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Which hath an operation more divine

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Than breath or pen can give expressure to:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: All the commerce that you have had with Troy

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: As perfectly is ours as yours, my lord;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And better would it fit Achilles much

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To throw down Hector than Polyxena:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: But it must grieve young Pyrrhus now at home,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: When fame shall in our islands sound her trump,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And all the Greekish girls shall tripping sing,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: 'Great Hector's sister did Achilles win,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: But our great Ajax bravely beat down him.'

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Farewell, my lord: I as your lover speak;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The fool slides o'er the ice that you should break.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: To this effect, Achilles, have I moved you:

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: A woman impudent and mannish grown

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Is not more loathed than an effeminate man

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: In time of action. I stand condemn'd for this;

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: They think my little stomach to the war

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: And your great love to me restrains you thus:

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Sweet, rouse yourself; and the weak wanton Cupid

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Shall from your neck unloose his amorous fold,

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: And, like a dew-drop from the lion's mane,

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Be shook to air.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Shall Ajax fight with Hector?

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Ay, and perhaps receive much honour by him.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: I see my reputation is at stake

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: My fame is shrewdly gored.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: O, then, beware;

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Those wounds heal ill that men do give themselves:

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Omission to do what is necessary

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Seals a commission to a blank of danger;

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: And danger, like an ague, subtly taints

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Even then when we sit idly in the sun.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Go call Thersites hither, sweet Patroclus:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: I'll send the fool to Ajax and desire him

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: To invite the Trojan lords after the combat

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: To see us here unarm'd: I have a woman's longing,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: An appetite that I am sick withal,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: To see great Hector in his weeds of peace,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: To talk with him and to behold his visage,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Even to my full of view.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Enter THERSITES

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: A labour saved!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: A wonder!

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: What?

speaker: THERSITES
