text_entry: Ajax goes up and down the field, asking for himself.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: How so?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: He must fight singly to-morrow with Hector, and is so

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: prophetically proud of an heroical cudgelling that he

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: raves in saying nothing.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: How can that be?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Why, he stalks up and down like a peacock,--a stride

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: and a stand: ruminates like an hostess that hath no

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: arithmetic but her brain to set down her reckoning:

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: bites his lip with a politic regard, as who should

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: say 'There were wit in this head, an 'twould out;'

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: and so there is, but it lies as coldly in him as fire

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: in a flint, which will not show without knocking.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: The man's undone forever; for if Hector break not his

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: neck i' the combat, he'll break 't himself in

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: vain-glory. He knows not me: I said 'Good morrow,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Ajax;' and he replies 'Thanks, Agamemnon.' What think

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: you of this man that takes me for the general? He's

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: grown a very land-fish, language-less, a monster.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: A plague of opinion! a man may wear it on both

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: sides, like a leather jerkin.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Thou must be my ambassador to him, Thersites.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Who, I? why, he'll answer nobody; he professes not

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: answering: speaking is for beggars; he wears his

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: tongue in's arms. I will put on his presence: let

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Patroclus make demands to me, you shall see the

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: pageant of Ajax.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: To him, Patroclus; tell him I humbly desire the

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: valiant Ajax to invite the most valorous Hector

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: to come unarmed to my tent, and to procure

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: safe-conduct for his person of the magnanimous

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: and most illustrious six-or-seven-times-honoured

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: captain-general of the Grecian army, Agamemnon,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: et cetera. Do this.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Jove bless great Ajax!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Hum!

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: I come from the worthy Achilles,--

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Ha!

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Who most humbly desires you to invite Hector to his tent,--

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Hum!

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: And to procure safe-conduct from Agamemnon.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Agamemnon!

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Ay, my lord.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Ha!

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: What say you to't?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: God b' wi' you, with all my heart.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Your answer, sir.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: If to-morrow be a fair day, by eleven o'clock it will

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: go one way or other: howsoever, he shall pay for me

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: ere he has me.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Your answer, sir.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Fare you well, with all my heart.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Why, but he is not in this tune, is he?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: No, but he's out o' tune thus. What music will be in

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: him when Hector has knocked out his brains, I know

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: not; but, I am sure, none, unless the fiddler Apollo

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: get his sinews to make catlings on.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Come, thou shalt bear a letter to him straight.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Let me bear another to his horse; for that's the more

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: capable creature.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: My mind is troubled, like a fountain stirr'd;

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: And I myself see not the bottom of it.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Exeunt ACHILLES and PATROCLUS

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Would the fountain of your mind were clear again,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: that I might water an ass at it! I had rather be a

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: tick in a sheep than such a valiant ignorance.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: SCENE I. Troy. A street.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a  torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: See, ho! who is that there?

speaker: DEIPHOBUS
text_entry: It is the Lord AEneas.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Is the prince there in person?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Had I so good occasion to lie long

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: As you, prince Paris, nothing but heavenly business

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Should rob my bed-mate of my company.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: That's my mind too. Good morrow, Lord AEneas.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: A valiant Greek, AEneas,--take his hand,--

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Witness the process of your speech, wherein

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: You told how Diomed, a whole week by days,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Did haunt you in the field.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Health to you, valiant sir,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: During all question of the gentle truce;

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: But when I meet you arm'd, as black defiance

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: As heart can think or courage execute.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: The one and other Diomed embraces.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Our bloods are now in calm; and, so long, health!

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: But when contention and occasion meet,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: By Jove, I'll play the hunter for thy life

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: With all my force, pursuit and policy.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: And thou shalt hunt a lion, that will fly

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: With his face backward. In humane gentleness,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Welcome to Troy! now, by Anchises' life,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Welcome, indeed! By Venus' hand I swear,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: No man alive can love in such a sort

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: The thing he means to kill more excellently.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: We sympathize: Jove, let AEneas live,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: If to my sword his fate be not the glory,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: A thousand complete courses of the sun!

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: But, in mine emulous honour, let him die,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: With every joint a wound, and that to-morrow!

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: We know each other well.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: We do; and long to know each other worse.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: This is the most despiteful gentle greeting,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: The noblest hateful love, that e'er I heard of.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: What business, lord, so early?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: I was sent for to the king; but why, I know not.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: His purpose meets you: 'twas to bring this Greek

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: To Calchas' house, and there to render him,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: For the enfreed Antenor, the fair Cressid:

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Let's have your company, or, if you please,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Haste there before us: I constantly do think--

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Or rather, call my thought a certain knowledge--

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: My brother Troilus lodges there to-night:

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Rouse him and give him note of our approach.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: With the whole quality wherefore: I fear

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: We shall be much unwelcome.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: That I assure you:

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Troilus had rather Troy were borne to Greece

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Than Cressid borne from Troy.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: There is no help;

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: The bitter disposition of the time

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Will have it so. On, lord; we'll follow you.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Good morrow, all.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Exit with Servant

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And tell me, noble Diomed, faith, tell me true,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Even in the soul of sound good-fellowship,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Who, in your thoughts, merits fair Helen best,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Myself or Menelaus?

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Both alike:

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: He merits well to have her, that doth seek her,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Not making any scruple of her soilure,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: With such a hell of pain and world of charge,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: And you as well to keep her, that defend her,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Not palating the taste of her dishonour,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: With such a costly loss of wealth and friends:

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: He, like a puling cuckold, would drink up

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: The lees and dregs of a flat tamed piece;

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: You, like a lecher, out of whorish loins

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Are pleased to breed out your inheritors:

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Both merits poised, each weighs nor less nor more;

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: But he as he, the heavier for a whore.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: You are too bitter to your countrywoman.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: She's bitter to her country: hear me, Paris:

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: For every false drop in her bawdy veins

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: A Grecian's life hath sunk; for every scruple

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Of her contaminated carrion weight,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: A Trojan hath been slain: since she could speak,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: She hath not given so many good words breath

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: As for her Greeks and Trojans suffer'd death.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Fair Diomed, you do as chapmen do,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Dispraise the thing that you desire to buy:

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: But we in silence hold this virtue well,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: We'll but commend what we intend to sell.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Here lies our way.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Enter TROILUS and CRESSIDA

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Dear, trouble not yourself: the morn is cold.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Then, sweet my lord, I'll call mine uncle down;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: He shall unbolt the gates.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Trouble him not;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To bed, to bed: sleep kill those pretty eyes,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And give as soft attachment to thy senses

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As infants' empty of all thought!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Good morrow, then.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I prithee now, to bed.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Are you a-weary of me?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: O Cressida! but that the busy day,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Waked by the lark, hath roused the ribald crows,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And dreaming night will hide our joys no longer,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I would not from thee.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Night hath been too brief.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Beshrew the witch! with venomous wights she stays

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As tediously as hell, but flies the grasps of love

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: With wings more momentary-swift than thought.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: You will catch cold, and curse me.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Prithee, tarry:

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: You men will never tarry.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: O foolish Cressid! I might have still held off,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: And then you would have tarried. Hark!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: there's one up.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: [Within]  What, 's all the doors open here?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: It is your uncle.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: A pestilence on him! now will he be mocking:

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I shall have such a life!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Enter PANDARUS

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: How now, how now! how go maidenheads? Here, you

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: maid! where's my cousin Cressid?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Go hang yourself, you naughty mocking uncle!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: You bring me to do, and then you flout me too.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: To do what? to do what? let her say

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: what: what have I brought you to do?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Come, come, beshrew your heart! you'll ne'er be good,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Nor suffer others.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Ha! ha! Alas, poor wretch! ah, poor capocchia!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: hast not slept to-night? would he not, a naughty

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: man, let it sleep? a bugbear take him!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Did not I tell you? Would he were knock'd i' the head!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Knocking within

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Who's that at door? good uncle, go and see.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: My lord, come you again into my chamber:

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: You smile and mock me, as if I meant naughtily.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Ha, ha!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Come, you are deceived, I think of no such thing.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Knocking within

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: How earnestly they knock! Pray you, come in:

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I would not for half Troy have you seen here.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Exeunt TROILUS and CRESSIDA

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Who's there? what's the matter? will you beat

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: down the door? How now! what's the matter?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Enter AENEAS

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Good morrow, lord, good morrow.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Who's there? my Lord AEneas! By my troth,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: I knew you not: what news with you so early?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Is not Prince Troilus here?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Here! what should he do here?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Come, he is here, my lord; do not deny him:

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: It doth import him much to speak with me.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Is he here, say you? 'tis more than I know, I'll

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: be sworn: for my own part, I came in late. What

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: should he do here?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Who!--nay, then: come, come, you'll do him wrong

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: ere you're ware: you'll be so true to him, to be

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: false to him: do not you know of him, but yet go

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: fetch him hither; go.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Re-enter TROILUS

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: How now! what's the matter?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: My lord, I scarce have leisure to salute you,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: My matter is so rash: there is at hand

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Paris your brother, and Deiphobus,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: The Grecian Diomed, and our Antenor

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Deliver'd to us; and for him forthwith,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Ere the first sacrifice, within this hour,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: We must give up to Diomedes' hand

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: The Lady Cressida.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Is it so concluded?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: By Priam and the general state of Troy:

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: They are at hand and ready to effect it.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: How my achievements mock me!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I will go meet them: and, my Lord AEneas,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: We met by chance; you did not find me here.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Good, good, my lord; the secrets of nature

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Have not more gift in taciturnity.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Exeunt TROILUS and AENEAS

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Is't possible? no sooner got but lost? The devil

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: take Antenor! the young prince will go mad: a

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: plague upon Antenor! I would they had broke 's neck!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Re-enter CRESSIDA

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: How now! what's the matter? who was here?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Ah, ah!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Why sigh you so profoundly? where's my lord? gone!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Tell me, sweet uncle, what's the matter?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Would I were as deep under the earth as I am above!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: O the gods! what's the matter?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Prithee, get thee in: would thou hadst ne'er been

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: born! I knew thou wouldst be his death. O, poor

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: gentleman! A plague upon Antenor!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Good uncle, I beseech you, on my knees! beseech you,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: what's the matter?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Thou must be gone, wench, thou must be gone; thou

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: art changed for Antenor: thou must to thy father,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: and be gone from Troilus: 'twill be his death;

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: 'twill be his bane; he cannot bear it.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: O you immortal gods! I will not go.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Thou must.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I will not, uncle: I have forgot my father;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I know no touch of consanguinity;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: No kin no love, no blood, no soul so near me

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: As the sweet Troilus. O you gods divine!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Make Cressid's name the very crown of falsehood,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: If ever she leave Troilus! Time, force, and death,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Do to this body what extremes you can;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: But the strong base and building of my love

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Is as the very centre of the earth,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Drawing all things to it. I'll go in and weep,--

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Do, do.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Tear my bright hair and scratch my praised cheeks,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Crack my clear voice with sobs and break my heart

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: With sounding Troilus. I will not go from Troy.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: SCENE III. The same. Street before Pandarus' house.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Enter PARIS, TROILUS, AENEAS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, and DIOMEDES

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: It is great morning, and the hour prefix'd

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Of her delivery to this valiant Greek

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Comes fast upon. Good my brother Troilus,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Tell you the lady what she is to do,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And haste her to the purpose.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Walk into her house;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I'll bring her to the Grecian presently:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And to his hand when I deliver her,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Think it an altar, and thy brother Troilus

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: A priest there offering to it his own heart.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: I know what 'tis to love;

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And would, as I shall pity, I could help!

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Please you walk in, my lords.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Enter PANDARUS and CRESSIDA

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Be moderate, be moderate.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Why tell you me of moderation?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: The grief is fine, full, perfect, that I taste,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: And violenteth in a sense as strong

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: As that which causeth it: how can I moderate it?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: If I could temporize with my affection,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Or brew it to a weak and colder palate,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: The like allayment could I give my grief.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: My love admits no qualifying dross;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: No more my grief, in such a precious loss.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Here, here, here he comes.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Enter TROILUS

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Ah, sweet ducks!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: O Troilus! Troilus!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Embracing him

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: What a pair of spectacles is here!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Let me embrace too. 'O heart,' as the goodly saying is,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: '--O heart, heavy heart,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Why sigh'st thou without breaking?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: where he answers again,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: 'Because thou canst not ease thy smart

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: By friendship nor by speaking.'

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: There was never a truer rhyme. Let us cast away

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: nothing, for we may live to have need of such a

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: verse: we see it, we see it. How now, lambs?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Cressid, I love thee in so strain'd a purity,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That the bless'd gods, as angry with my fancy,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: More bright in zeal than the devotion which

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Cold lips blow to their deities, take thee from me.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Have the gods envy?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Ay, ay, ay, ay; 'tis too plain a case.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: And is it true that I must go from Troy?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: A hateful truth.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: What, and from Troilus too?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: From Troy and Troilus.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Is it possible?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And suddenly; where injury of chance

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Puts back leave-taking, justles roughly by

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: All time of pause, rudely beguiles our lips

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Of all rejoindure, forcibly prevents

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Our lock'd embrasures, strangles our dear vows

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Even in the birth of our own labouring breath:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: We two, that with so many thousand sighs

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Did buy each other, must poorly sell ourselves

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: With the rude brevity and discharge of one.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Injurious time now with a robber's haste

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Crams his rich thievery up, he knows not how:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As many farewells as be stars in heaven,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: With distinct breath and consign'd kisses to them,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: He fumbles up into a lose adieu,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And scants us with a single famish'd kiss,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Distasted with the salt of broken tears.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: [Within]  My lord, is the lady ready?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Hark! you are call'd: some say the Genius so

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Cries 'come' to him that instantly must die.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Bid them have patience; she shall come anon.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Where are my tears? rain, to lay this wind, or

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: my heart will be blown up by the root.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I must then to the Grecians?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: No remedy.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: A woful Cressid 'mongst the merry Greeks!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: When shall we see again?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Hear me, my love: be thou but true of heart,--

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I true! how now! what wicked deem is this?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Nay, we must use expostulation kindly,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: For it is parting from us:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I speak not 'be thou true,' as fearing thee,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: For I will throw my glove to Death himself,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That there's no maculation in thy heart:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But 'be thou true,' say I, to fashion in

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: My sequent protestation; be thou true,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And I will see thee.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: O, you shall be exposed, my lord, to dangers

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: As infinite as imminent! but I'll be true.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And I'll grow friend with danger. Wear this sleeve.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: And you this glove. When shall I see you?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I will corrupt the Grecian sentinels,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To give thee nightly visitation.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But yet be true.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: O heavens! 'be true' again!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Hear while I speak it, love:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The Grecian youths are full of quality;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: They're loving, well composed with gifts of nature,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Flowing and swelling o'er with arts and exercise:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: How novelty may move, and parts with person,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Alas, a kind of godly jealousy--

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Which, I beseech you, call a virtuous sin--

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Makes me afeard.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: O heavens! you love me not.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Die I a villain, then!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: In this I do not call your faith in question

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: So mainly as my merit: I cannot sing,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Nor heel the high lavolt, nor sweeten talk,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Nor play at subtle games; fair virtues all,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To which the Grecians are most prompt and pregnant:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But I can tell that in each grace of these

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: There lurks a still and dumb-discoursive devil

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That tempts most cunningly: but be not tempted.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Do you think I will?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: No.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But something may be done that we will not:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And sometimes we are devils to ourselves,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: When we will tempt the frailty of our powers,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Presuming on their changeful potency.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: [Within]  Nay, good my lord,--

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Come, kiss; and let us part.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: [Within]  Brother Troilus!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Good brother, come you hither;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And bring AEneas and the Grecian with you.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: My lord, will you be true?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Who, I? alas, it is my vice, my fault:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Whiles others fish with craft for great opinion,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I with great truth catch mere simplicity;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Whilst some with cunning gild their copper crowns,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: With truth and plainness I do wear mine bare.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Fear not my truth: the moral of my wit

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Is 'plain and true;' there's all the reach of it.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Enter AENEAS, PARIS, ANTENOR, DEIPHOBUS, and DIOMEDES

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Welcome, Sir Diomed! here is the lady

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Which for Antenor we deliver you:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: At the port, lord, I'll give her to thy hand,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And by the way possess thee what she is.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Entreat her fair; and, by my soul, fair Greek,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: If e'er thou stand at mercy of my sword,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Name Cressida and thy life shall be as safe

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As Priam is in Ilion.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Fair Lady Cressid,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: So please you, save the thanks this prince expects:

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: The lustre in your eye, heaven in your cheek,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Pleads your fair usage; and to Diomed

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: You shall be mistress, and command him wholly.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Grecian, thou dost not use me courteously,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To shame the zeal of my petition to thee

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: In praising her: I tell thee, lord of Greece,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: She is as far high-soaring o'er thy praises

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As thou unworthy to be call'd her servant.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I charge thee use her well, even for my charge;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: For, by the dreadful Pluto, if thou dost not,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Though the great bulk Achilles be thy guard,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I'll cut thy throat.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: O, be not moved, Prince Troilus:

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Let me be privileged by my place and message,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: To be a speaker free; when I am hence

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: I'll answer to my lust: and know you, lord,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: I'll nothing do on charge: to her own worth

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: She shall be prized; but that you say 'be't so,'

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: I'll speak it in my spirit and honour, 'no.'

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Come, to the port. I'll tell thee, Diomed,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: This brave shall oft make thee to hide thy head.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Lady, give me your hand, and, as we walk,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To our own selves bend we our needful talk.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Exeunt TROILUS, CRESSIDA, and DIOMEDES

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Trumpet within

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Hark! Hector's trumpet.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: How have we spent this morning!

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: The prince must think me tardy and remiss,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: That sore to ride before him to the field.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: 'Tis Troilus' fault: come, come, to field with him.

speaker: DEIPHOBUS
text_entry: Let us make ready straight.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Yea, with a bridegroom's fresh alacrity,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Let us address to tend on Hector's heels:

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: The glory of our Troy doth this day lie

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: On his fair worth and single chivalry.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Enter AJAX, armed; AGAMEMNON, ACHILLES, PATROCLUS, MENELAUS, ULYSSES, NESTOR, and others

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Here art thou in appointment fresh and fair,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Anticipating time with starting courage.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Give with thy trumpet a loud note to Troy,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Thou dreadful Ajax; that the appalled air

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: May pierce the head of the great combatant

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: And hale him hither.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Thou, trumpet, there's my purse.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Now crack thy lungs, and split thy brazen pipe:

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Blow, villain, till thy sphered bias cheek

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Outswell the colic of puff'd Aquilon:

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Come, stretch thy chest and let thy eyes spout blood;

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Thou blow'st for Hector.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Trumpet sounds

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: No trumpet answers.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: 'Tis but early days.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Is not yond Diomed, with Calchas' daughter?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: 'Tis he, I ken the manner of his gait;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He rises on the toe: that spirit of his

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: In aspiration lifts him from the earth.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Enter DIOMEDES, with CRESSIDA

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Is this the Lady Cressid?

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Even she.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Most dearly welcome to the Greeks, sweet lady.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Our general doth salute you with a kiss.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Yet is the kindness but particular;

speaker: ULYSSES
