speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: palsies, raw eyes, dirt-rotten livers, wheezing

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: lungs, bladders full of imposthume, sciaticas,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: limekilns i' the palm, incurable bone-ache, and the

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: rivelled fee-simple of the tetter, take and take

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: again such preposterous discoveries!

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Why thou damnable box of envy, thou, what meanest

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: thou to curse thus?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Do I curse thee?

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Why no, you ruinous butt, you whoreson

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: indistinguishable cur, no.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: No! why art thou then exasperate, thou idle

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: immaterial skein of sleave-silk, thou green sarcenet

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: flap for a sore eye, thou tassel of a prodigal's

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: purse, thou? Ah, how the poor world is pestered

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: with such waterflies, diminutives of nature!

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Out, gall!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Finch-egg!

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: My sweet Patroclus, I am thwarted quite

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: From my great purpose in to-morrow's battle.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Here is a letter from Queen Hecuba,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: A token from her daughter, my fair love,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Both taxing me and gaging me to keep

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: An oath that I have sworn. I will not break it:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Fall Greeks; fail fame; honour or go or stay;

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: My major vow lies here, this I'll obey.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Come, come, Thersites, help to trim my tent:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: This night in banqueting must all be spent.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Away, Patroclus!

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Exeunt ACHILLES and PATROCLUS

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: With too much blood and too little brain, these two

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: may run mad; but, if with too much brain and too

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: little blood they do, I'll be a curer of madmen.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Here's Agamemnon, an honest fellow enough and one

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: that loves quails; but he has not so much brain as

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: earwax: and the goodly transformation of Jupiter

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: there, his brother, the bull,--the primitive statue,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: and oblique memorial of cuckolds; a thrifty

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: shoeing-horn in a chain, hanging at his brother's

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: leg,--to what form but that he is, should wit larded

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: with malice and malice forced with wit turn him to?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: To an ass, were nothing; he is both ass and ox: to

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: an ox, were nothing; he is both ox and ass. To be a

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: dog, a mule, a cat, a fitchew, a toad, a lizard, an

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: owl, a puttock, or a herring without a roe, I would

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: not care; but to be Menelaus, I would conspire

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: against destiny. Ask me not, what I would be, if I

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: were not Thersites; for I care not to be the louse

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: of a lazar, so I were not Menelaus! Hey-day!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: spirits and fires!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter HECTOR, TROILUS, AJAX, AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, MENELAUS, and DIOMEDES, with lights

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: We go wrong, we go wrong.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: No, yonder 'tis;

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: There, where we see the lights.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I trouble you.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: No, not a whit.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Here comes himself to guide you.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Re-enter ACHILLES

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Welcome, brave Hector; welcome, princes all.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: So now, fair prince of Troy, I bid good night.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Ajax commands the guard to tend on you.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Thanks and good night to the Greeks' general.

speaker: MENELAUS
text_entry: Good night, my lord.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Good night, sweet lord Menelaus.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Sweet draught: 'sweet' quoth 'a! sweet sink,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: sweet sewer.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Good night and welcome, both at once, to those

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: That go or tarry.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Good night.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Exeunt AGAMEMNON and MENELAUS

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Old Nestor tarries; and you too, Diomed,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Keep Hector company an hour or two.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: I cannot, lord; I have important business,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: The tide whereof is now. Good night, great Hector.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Give me your hand.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: [Aside to TROILUS]  Follow his torch; he goes to

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Calchas' tent:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: I'll keep you company.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Sweet sir, you honour me.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: And so, good night.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Exit DIOMEDES; ULYSSES and TROILUS following

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Come, come, enter my tent.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Exeunt ACHILLES, HECTOR, AJAX, and NESTOR

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: That same Diomed's a false-hearted rogue, a most

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: unjust knave; I will no more trust him when he leers

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: than I will a serpent when he hisses: he will spend

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: his mouth, and promise, like Brabbler the hound:

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: but when he performs, astronomers foretell it; it

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: is prodigious, there will come some change; the sun

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: borrows of the moon, when Diomed keeps his

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: word. I will rather leave to see Hector, than

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: not to dog him: they say he keeps a Trojan

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: drab, and uses the traitor Calchas' tent: I'll

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: after. Nothing but lechery! all incontinent varlets!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter DIOMEDES

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: What, are you up here, ho? speak.

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: [Within]  Who calls?

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Calchas, I think. Where's your daughter?

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: [Within]  She comes to you.

speaker: CALCHAS
text_entry: Enter TROILUS and ULYSSES, at a distance; after them, THERSITES

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Stand where the torch may not discover us.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Enter CRESSIDA

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Cressid comes forth to him.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: How now, my charge!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Now, my sweet guardian! Hark, a word with you.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Whispers

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Yea, so familiar!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: She will sing any man at first sight.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: And any man may sing her, if he can take her cliff;

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: she's noted.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Will you remember?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Remember! yes.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Nay, but do, then;

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: And let your mind be coupled with your words.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: What should she remember?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: List.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Sweet honey Greek, tempt me no more to folly.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Roguery!

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Nay, then,--

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I'll tell you what,--

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Foh, foh! come, tell a pin: you are forsworn.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: In faith, I cannot: what would you have me do?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: A juggling trick,--to be secretly open.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: What did you swear you would bestow on me?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I prithee, do not hold me to mine oath;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Bid me do any thing but that, sweet Greek.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Good night.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Hold, patience!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: How now, Trojan!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Diomed,--

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: No, no, good night: I'll be your fool no more.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Thy better must.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Hark, one word in your ear.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: O plague and madness!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: You are moved, prince; let us depart, I pray you,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Lest your displeasure should enlarge itself

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To wrathful terms: this place is dangerous;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The time right deadly; I beseech you, go.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Behold, I pray you!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Nay, good my lord, go off:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: You flow to great distraction; come, my lord.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I pray thee, stay.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: You have not patience; come.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I pray you, stay; by hell and all hell's torments

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I will not speak a word!

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: And so, good night.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Nay, but you part in anger.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Doth that grieve thee?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: O wither'd truth!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Why, how now, lord!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: By Jove,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I will be patient.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Guardian!--why, Greek!

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Foh, foh! adieu; you palter.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: In faith, I do not: come hither once again.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: You shake, my lord, at something: will you go?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: You will break out.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: She strokes his cheek!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Come, come.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Nay, stay; by Jove, I will not speak a word:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: There is between my will and all offences

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: A guard of patience: stay a little while.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: How the devil Luxury, with his fat rump and

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: potato-finger, tickles these together! Fry, lechery, fry!

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: But will you, then?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: In faith, I will, la; never trust me else.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Give me some token for the surety of it.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I'll fetch you one.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: You have sworn patience.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Fear me not, sweet lord;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I will not be myself, nor have cognition

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Of what I feel: I am all patience.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Re-enter CRESSIDA

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Now the pledge; now, now, now!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Here, Diomed, keep this sleeve.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: O beauty! where is thy faith?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: My lord,--

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I will be patient; outwardly I will.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: You look upon that sleeve; behold it well.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: He loved me--O false wench!--Give't me again.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Whose was't?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: It is no matter, now I have't again.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I will not meet with you to-morrow night:

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I prithee, Diomed, visit me no more.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Now she sharpens: well said, whetstone!

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: I shall have it.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: What, this?

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Ay, that.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: O, all you gods! O pretty, pretty pledge!

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Thy master now lies thinking in his bed

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Of thee and me, and sighs, and takes my glove,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: And gives memorial dainty kisses to it,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: As I kiss thee. Nay, do not snatch it from me;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: He that takes that doth take my heart withal.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: I had your heart before, this follows it.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I did swear patience.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: You shall not have it, Diomed; faith, you shall not;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I'll give you something else.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: I will have this: whose was it?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: It is no matter.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Come, tell me whose it was.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: 'Twas one's that loved me better than you will.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: But, now you have it, take it.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Whose was it?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: By all Diana's waiting-women yond,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: And by herself, I will not tell you whose.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: To-morrow will I wear it on my helm,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: And grieve his spirit that dares not challenge it.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Wert thou the devil, and worest it on thy horn,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: It should be challenged.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Well, well, 'tis done, 'tis past: and yet it is not;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I will not keep my word.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Why, then, farewell;

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Thou never shalt mock Diomed again.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: You shall not go: one cannot speak a word,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: But it straight starts you.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: I do not like this fooling.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Nor I, by Pluto: but that that likes not you pleases me best.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: What, shall I come? the hour?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Ay, come:--O Jove!--do come:--I shall be plagued.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Farewell till then.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Good night: I prithee, come.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Exit DIOMEDES

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Troilus, farewell! one eye yet looks on thee

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: But with my heart the other eye doth see.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Ah, poor our sex! this fault in us I find,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: The error of our eye directs our mind:

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: What error leads must err; O, then conclude

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Minds sway'd by eyes are full of turpitude.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: A proof of strength she could not publish more,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Unless she said ' My mind is now turn'd whore.'

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: All's done, my lord.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: It is.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Why stay we, then?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To make a recordation to my soul

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Of every syllable that here was spoke.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But if I tell how these two did co-act,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Shall I not lie in publishing a truth?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Sith yet there is a credence in my heart,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: An esperance so obstinately strong,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That doth invert the attest of eyes and ears,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As if those organs had deceptious functions,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Created only to calumniate.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Was Cressid here?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: I cannot conjure, Trojan.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: She was not, sure.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Most sure she was.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Why, my negation hath no taste of madness.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Nor mine, my lord: Cressid was here but now.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Let it not be believed for womanhood!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Think, we had mothers; do not give advantage

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To stubborn critics, apt, without a theme,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: For depravation, to square the general sex

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: By Cressid's rule: rather think this not Cressid.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: What hath she done, prince, that can soil our mothers?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Nothing at all, unless that this were she.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Will he swagger himself out on's own eyes?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: This she? no, this is Diomed's Cressida:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: If beauty have a soul, this is not she;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: If souls guide vows, if vows be sanctimonies,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: If sanctimony be the gods' delight,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: If there be rule in unity itself,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: This is not she. O madness of discourse,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That cause sets up with and against itself!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Bi-fold authority! where reason can revolt

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Without perdition, and loss assume all reason

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Without revolt: this is, and is not, Cressid.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Within my soul there doth conduce a fight

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Of this strange nature that a thing inseparate

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Divides more wider than the sky and earth,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And yet the spacious breadth of this division

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Admits no orifex for a point as subtle

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As Ariachne's broken woof to enter.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Instance, O instance! strong as Pluto's gates;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Cressid is mine, tied with the bonds of heaven:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Instance, O instance! strong as heaven itself;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The bonds of heaven are slipp'd, dissolved, and loosed;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And with another knot, five-finger-tied,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The fractions of her faith, orts of her love,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The fragments, scraps, the bits and greasy relics

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Of her o'er-eaten faith, are bound to Diomed.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: May worthy Troilus be half attach'd

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: With that which here his passion doth express?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Ay, Greek; and that shall be divulged well

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: In characters as red as Mars his heart

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Inflamed with Venus: never did young man fancy

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: With so eternal and so fix'd a soul.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Hark, Greek: as much as I do Cressid love,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: So much by weight hate I her Diomed:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That sleeve is mine that he'll bear on his helm;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Were it a casque composed by Vulcan's skill,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: My sword should bite it: not the dreadful spout

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Which shipmen do the hurricano call,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Constringed in mass by the almighty sun,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Shall dizzy with more clamour Neptune's ear

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: In his descent than shall my prompted sword

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Falling on Diomed.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: He'll tickle it for his concupy.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: O Cressid! O false Cressid! false, false, false!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Let all untruths stand by thy stained name,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And they'll seem glorious.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: O, contain yourself

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Your passion draws ears hither.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Enter AENEAS

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: I have been seeking you this hour, my lord:

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Hector, by this, is arming him in Troy;

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Ajax, your guard, stays to conduct you home.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Have with you, prince. My courteous lord, adieu.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Farewell, revolted fair! and, Diomed,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Stand fast, and wear a castle on thy head!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: I'll bring you to the gates.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Accept distracted thanks.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Exeunt TROILUS, AENEAS, and ULYSSES

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Would I could meet that rogue Diomed! I would

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: croak like a raven; I would bode, I would bode.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Patroclus will give me any thing for the

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: intelligence of this whore: the parrot will not

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: do more for an almond than he for a commodious drab.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Lechery, lechery; still, wars and lechery; nothing

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: else holds fashion: a burning devil take them!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter HECTOR and ANDROMACHE

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: When was my lord so much ungently temper'd,

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: To stop his ears against admonishment?

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: Unarm, unarm, and do not fight to-day.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: You train me to offend you; get you in:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: By all the everlasting gods, I'll go!

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: My dreams will, sure, prove ominous to the day.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: No more, I say.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Enter CASSANDRA

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Where is my brother Hector?

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: Here, sister; arm'd, and bloody in intent.

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: Consort with me in loud and dear petition,

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: Pursue we him on knees; for I have dream'd

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: Of bloody turbulence, and this whole night

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: Hath nothing been but shapes and forms of slaughter.

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: O, 'tis true.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Ho! bid my trumpet sound!

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: No notes of sally, for the heavens, sweet brother.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Be gone, I say: the gods have heard me swear.

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: The gods are deaf to hot and peevish vows:

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: They are polluted offerings, more abhorr'd

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Than spotted livers in the sacrifice.

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: O, be persuaded! do not count it holy

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: To hurt by being just: it is as lawful,

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: For we would give much, to use violent thefts,

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: And rob in the behalf of charity.

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: It is the purpose that makes strong the vow;

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: But vows to every purpose must not hold:

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Unarm, sweet Hector.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Hold you still, I say;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Mine honour keeps the weather of my fate:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Lie every man holds dear; but the brave man

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Holds honour far more precious-dear than life.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Enter TROILUS

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: How now, young man! mean'st thou to fight to-day?

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: Cassandra, call my father to persuade.

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: Exit CASSANDRA

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: No, faith, young Troilus; doff thy harness, youth;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I am to-day i' the vein of chivalry:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Let grow thy sinews till their knots be strong,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: And tempt not yet the brushes of the war.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Unarm thee, go, and doubt thou not, brave boy,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I'll stand to-day for thee and me and Troy.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Brother, you have a vice of mercy in you,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Which better fits a lion than a man.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: What vice is that, good Troilus? chide me for it.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: When many times the captive Grecian falls,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Even in the fan and wind of your fair sword,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: You bid them rise, and live.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: O,'tis fair play.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Fool's play, by heaven, Hector.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: How now! how now!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: For the love of all the gods,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Let's leave the hermit pity with our mothers,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And when we have our armours buckled on,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The venom'd vengeance ride upon our swords,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Spur them to ruthful work, rein them from ruth.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Fie, savage, fie!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Hector, then 'tis wars.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Troilus, I would not have you fight to-day.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Who should withhold me?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Not fate, obedience, nor the hand of Mars

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Beckoning with fiery truncheon my retire;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Not Priamus and Hecuba on knees,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Their eyes o'ergalled with recourse of tears;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Not you, my brother, with your true sword drawn,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Opposed to  hinder me, should stop my way,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But by my ruin.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Re-enter CASSANDRA, with PRIAM

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Lay hold upon him, Priam, hold him fast:

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: He is thy crutch; now if thou lose thy stay,

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Thou on him leaning, and all Troy on thee,

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Fall all together.

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Come, Hector, come, go back:

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Thy wife hath dream'd; thy mother hath had visions;

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Cassandra doth foresee; and I myself

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Am like a prophet suddenly enrapt

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: To tell thee that this day is ominous:

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Therefore, come back.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: AEneas is a-field;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: And I do stand engaged to many Greeks,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Even in the faith of valour, to appear

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: This morning to them.

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Ay, but thou shalt not go.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I must not break my faith.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: You know me dutiful; therefore, dear sir,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Let me not shame respect; but give me leave

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: To take that course by your consent and voice,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Which you do here forbid me, royal Priam.

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: O Priam, yield not to him!

speaker: ANDROMACHE
text_entry: Do not, dear father.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Andromache, I am offended with you:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Upon the love you bear me, get you in.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Exit ANDROMACHE

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: This foolish, dreaming, superstitious girl

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Makes all these bodements.

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: O, farewell, dear Hector!

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Look, how thou diest! look, how thy eye turns pale!

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Look, how thy wounds do bleed at many vents!

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Hark, how Troy roars! how Hecuba cries out!

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: How poor Andromache shrills her dolours forth!

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Behold, distraction, frenzy and amazement,

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Like witless antics, one another meet,

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: And all cry, Hector! Hector's dead! O Hector!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Away! away!

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Farewell: yet, soft! Hector! take my leave:

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Thou dost thyself and all our Troy deceive.

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: You are amazed, my liege, at her exclaim:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Go in and cheer the town: we'll forth and fight,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Do deeds worth praise and tell you them at night.

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Farewell: the gods with safety stand about thee!

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Exeunt severally PRIAM and HECTOR. Alarums

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: They are at it, hark! Proud Diomed, believe,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I come to lose my arm, or win my sleeve.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Enter PANDARUS

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Do you hear, my lord? do you hear?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: What now?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Here's a letter come from yond poor girl.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Let me read.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: A whoreson tisick, a whoreson rascally tisick so

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: troubles me, and the foolish fortune of this girl;

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: and what one thing, what another, that I shall

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: leave you one o' these days: and I have a rheum

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: in mine eyes too, and such an ache in my bones

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: that, unless a man were cursed, I cannot tell what

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: to think on't. What says she there?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Words, words, mere words, no matter from the heart:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The effect doth operate another way.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Tearing the letter

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Go, wind, to wind, there turn and change together.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: My love with words and errors still she feeds;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But edifies another with her deeds.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Exeunt severally

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: SCENE IV. Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Alarums: excursions. Enter THERSITES

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Now they are clapper-clawing one another; I'll go

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: look on. That dissembling abominable varlets Diomed,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: has got that same scurvy doting foolish young knave's

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: sleeve of Troy there in his helm: I would fain see

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: them meet; that that same young Trojan ass, that

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: loves the whore there, might send that Greekish

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: whore-masterly villain, with the sleeve, back to the

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: dissembling luxurious drab, of a sleeveless errand.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: O' the t'other side, the policy of those crafty

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: swearing rascals, that stale old mouse-eaten dry

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: cheese, Nestor, and that same dog-fox, Ulysses, is

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: not proved worthy a blackberry: they set me up, in

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: policy, that mongrel cur, Ajax, against that dog of

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: as bad a kind, Achilles: and now is the cur Ajax

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: prouder than the cur Achilles, and will not arm

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: to-day; whereupon the Grecians begin to proclaim

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: barbarism, and policy grows into an ill opinion.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Soft! here comes sleeve, and t'other.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter DIOMEDES, TROILUS following

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Fly not; for shouldst thou take the river Styx,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I would swim after.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Thou dost miscall retire:

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: I do not fly, but advantageous care

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Withdrew me from the odds of multitude:

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Have at thee!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Hold thy whore, Grecian!--now for thy whore,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Trojan!--now the sleeve, now the sleeve!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Exeunt TROILUS and DIOMEDES, fighting

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter HECTOR

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: What art thou, Greek? art thou for Hector's match?

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Art thou of blood and honour?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: No, no, I am a rascal; a scurvy railing knave:

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: a very filthy rogue.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I do believe thee: live.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Exit

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: God-a-mercy, that thou wilt believe me; but a

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: plague break thy neck for frightening me! What's

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: become of the wenching rogues? I think they have

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: swallowed one another: I would laugh at that

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: miracle: yet, in a sort, lechery eats itself.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: I'll seek them.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: SCENE V. Another part of the plains.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter DIOMEDES and a Servant

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Go, go, my servant, take thou Troilus' horse;

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Present the fair steed to my lady Cressid:

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Fellow, commend my service to her beauty;

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Tell her I have chastised the amorous Trojan,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: And am her knight by proof.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: I go, my lord.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Enter AGAMEMNON

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Renew, renew! The fierce Polydamas

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Hath beat down Menon: bastard Margarelon

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Hath Doreus prisoner,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: And stands colossus-wise, waving his beam,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Upon the pashed corses of the kings

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Epistrophus and Cedius: Polyxenes is slain,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Amphimachus and Thoas deadly hurt,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Patroclus ta'en or slain, and Palamedes

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Sore hurt and bruised: the dreadful Sagittary

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Appals our numbers: haste we, Diomed,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: To reinforcement, or we perish all.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Enter NESTOR

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Go, bear Patroclus' body to Achilles;

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: And bid the snail-paced Ajax arm for shame.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: There is a thousand Hectors in the field:

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Now here he fights on Galathe his horse,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: And there lacks work; anon he's there afoot,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: And there they fly or die, like scaled sculls

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Before the belching whale; then is he yonder,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: And there the strawy Greeks, ripe for his edge,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Fall down before him, like the mower's swath:

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Here, there, and every where, he leaves and takes,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Dexterity so obeying appetite

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: That what he will he does, and does so much

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: That proof is call'd impossibility.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Enter ULYSSES

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: O, courage, courage, princes! great Achilles

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Is arming, weeping, cursing, vowing vengeance:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Patroclus' wounds have roused his drowsy blood,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Together with his mangled Myrmidons,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That noseless, handless, hack'd and chipp'd, come to him,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Crying on Hector. Ajax hath lost a friend

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And foams at mouth, and he is arm'd and at it,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Roaring for Troilus, who hath done to-day

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Mad and fantastic execution,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Engaging and redeeming of himself

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: With such a careless force and forceless care

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: As if that luck, in very spite of cunning,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Bade him win all.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Enter AJAX

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Troilus! thou coward Troilus!

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Ay, there, there.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: So, so, we draw together.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Enter ACHILLES

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Where is this Hector?

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Come, come, thou boy-queller, show thy face;

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Know what it is to meet Achilles angry:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Hector? where's Hector? I will none but Hector.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Enter AJAX

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Troilus, thou coward Troilus, show thy head!

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Enter DIOMEDES

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Troilus, I say! where's Troilus?

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: What wouldst thou?

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: I would correct him.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Were I the general, thou shouldst have my office

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Ere that correction. Troilus, I say! what, Troilus!

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Enter TROILUS

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: O traitor Diomed! turn thy false face, thou traitor,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And pay thy life thou owest me for my horse!

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Ha, art thou there?

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: I'll fight with him alone: stand, Diomed.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: He is my prize; I will not look upon.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Come, both you cogging Greeks; have at you both!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Exeunt, fighting

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Enter HECTOR

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Yea, Troilus? O, well fought, my youngest brother!

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Enter ACHILLES

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Now do I see thee, ha! have at thee, Hector!

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Pause, if thou wilt.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: I do disdain thy courtesy, proud Trojan:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Be happy that my arms are out of use:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: My rest and negligence befriends thee now,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: But thou anon shalt hear of me again;

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Till when, go seek thy fortune.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Fare thee well:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I would have been much more a fresher man,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Had I expected thee. How now, my brother!

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Re-enter TROILUS

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Ajax hath ta'en AEneas: shall it be?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: No, by the flame of yonder glorious heaven,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: He shall not carry him: I'll be ta'en too,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Or bring him off: fate, hear me what I say!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I reck not though I end my life to-day.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Enter one in sumptuous armour

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Stand, stand, thou Greek; thou art a goodly mark:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: No? wilt thou not? I like thy armour well;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I'll frush it and unlock the rivets all,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: But I'll be master of it: wilt thou not,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: beast, abide?

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Why, then fly on, I'll hunt thee for thy hide.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: SCENE VII. Another part of the plains.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Enter ACHILLES, with Myrmidons

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Come here about me, you my Myrmidons;

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Mark what I say. Attend me where I wheel:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Strike not a stroke, but keep yourselves in breath:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: And when I have the bloody Hector found,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Empale him with your weapons round about;

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: In fellest manner execute your aims.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Follow me, sirs, and my proceedings eye:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: It is decreed Hector the great must die.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Enter MENELAUS and PARIS, fighting: then THERSITES

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: The cuckold and the cuckold-maker are at it. Now,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: bull! now, dog! 'Loo, Paris, 'loo! now my double-

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: henned sparrow! 'loo, Paris, 'loo! The bull has the

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: game: ware horns, ho!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Exeunt PARIS and MENELAUS

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter MARGARELON

speaker: MARGARELON
text_entry: Turn, slave, and fight.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: What art thou?

speaker: MARGARELON
text_entry: A bastard son of Priam's.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: I am a bastard too; I love bastards: I am a bastard

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: begot, bastard instructed, bastard in mind, bastard

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: in valour, in every thing illegitimate. One bear will

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: not bite another, and wherefore should one bastard?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Take heed, the quarrel's most ominous to us: if the

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: son of a whore fight for a whore, he tempts judgment:

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: farewell, bastard.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MARGARELON
text_entry: The devil take thee, coward!

speaker: MARGARELON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MARGARELON
text_entry: SCENE VIII. Another part of the plains.

speaker: MARGARELON
text_entry: Enter HECTOR

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Most putrefied core, so fair without,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Thy goodly armour thus hath cost thy life.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Now is my day's work done; I'll take good breath:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Rest, sword; thou hast thy fill of blood and death.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Puts off his helmet and hangs his shield behind him

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Enter ACHILLES and Myrmidons

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Look, Hector, how the sun begins to set;

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: How ugly night comes breathing at his heels:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Even with the vail and darking of the sun,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: To close the day up, Hector's life is done.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I am unarm'd; forego this vantage, Greek.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Strike, fellows, strike; this is the man I seek.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: HECTOR falls

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: So, Ilion, fall thou next! now, Troy, sink down!

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Here lies thy heart, thy sinews, and thy bone.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: On, Myrmidons, and cry you all amain,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: 'Achilles hath the mighty Hector slain.'

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: A retreat sounded

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Hark! a retire upon our Grecian part.

speaker: MYRMIDONS
text_entry: The Trojan trumpets sound the like, my lord.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: The dragon wing of night o'erspreads the earth,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: And, stickler-like, the armies separates.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: My half-supp'd sword, that frankly would have fed,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Pleased with this dainty bait, thus goes to bed.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Sheathes his sword

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Come, tie his body to my horse's tail;

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Along the field I will the Trojan trail.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: SCENE IX. Another part of the plains.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Enter AGAMEMNON, AJAX, MENELAUS, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and others, marching. Shouts within

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Hark! hark! what shout is that?

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Peace, drums!

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Within

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Achilles! Achilles! Hector's slain! Achilles.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: The bruit is, Hector's slain, and by Achilles.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: If it be so, yet bragless let it be;

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Great Hector was a man as good as he.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: March patiently along: let one be sent

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: To pray Achilles see us at our tent.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: If in his death the gods have us befriended,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Great Troy is ours, and our sharp wars are ended.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Exeunt, marching

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: SCENE X. Another part of the plains.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Enter AENEAS and Trojans

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Stand, ho! yet are we masters of the field:

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Never go home; here starve we out the night.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Enter TROILUS

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Hector is slain.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Hector! the gods forbid!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: He's dead; and at the murderer's horse's tail,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: In beastly sort, dragg'd through the shameful field.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Frown on, you heavens, effect your rage with speed!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Sit, gods, upon your thrones, and smile at Troy!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I say, at once let your brief plagues be mercy,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And linger not our sure destructions on!

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: My lord, you do discomfort all the host!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: You understand me not that tell me so:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I do not speak of flight, of fear, of death,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But dare all imminence that gods and men

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Address their dangers in. Hector is gone:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Who shall tell Priam so, or Hecuba?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Let him that will a screech-owl aye be call'd,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Go in to Troy, and say there, Hector's dead:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: There is a word will Priam turn to stone;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Make wells and Niobes of the maids and wives,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Cold statues of the youth, and, in a word,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Scare Troy out of itself. But, march away:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Hector is dead; there is no more to say.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Stay yet. You vile abominable tents,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Thus proudly pight upon our Phrygian plains,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Let Titan rise as early as he dare,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I'll through and through you! and, thou great-sized coward,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: No space of earth shall sunder our two hates:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I'll haunt thee like a wicked conscience still,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That mouldeth goblins swift as frenzy's thoughts.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Strike a free march to Troy! with comfort go:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Hope of revenge shall hide our inward woe.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Exeunt AENEAS and Trojans

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As TROILUS is going out, enter, from the other side, PANDARUS

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: But hear you, hear you!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Hence, broker-lackey! ignomy and shame

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Pursue thy life, and live aye with thy name!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: A goodly medicine for my aching bones! O world!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: world! world! thus is the poor agent despised!

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: O traitors and bawds, how earnestly are you set

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: a-work, and how ill requited! why should our

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: endeavour be so loved and the performance so loathed?

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: what verse for it? what instance for it? Let me see:

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Full merrily the humble-bee doth sing,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Till he hath lost his honey and his sting;

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: And being once subdued in armed tail,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Sweet honey and sweet notes together fail.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Good traders in the flesh, set this in your

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: painted cloths.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: As many as be here of pander's hall,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Your eyes, half out, weep out at Pandar's fall;

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Or if you cannot weep, yet give some groans,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Though not for me, yet for your aching bones.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Brethren and sisters of the hold-door trade,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Some two months hence my will shall here be made:

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: It should be now, but that my fear is this,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Some galled goose of Winchester would hiss:

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Till then I'll sweat and seek about for eases,

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: And at that time bequeathe you my diseases.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Exit
